title: Why are people against corporal punishment as a deterrent? - Quora

response.answer_text: Because there are side effects to corporal punishment that adults are either oblivious to or don’t care about. From an adult’s view, spanking appears to work. Many children won’t repeat the behavior because they don’t want to be spanked again. Does it matter why children don’t do it again? Yes, because they’re deciding based on how their actions affect them, not on how their actions affect others. If they avoid “bad” choices to avoid being spanked, then there’s little reason not to do something “bad” if they believe they can’t be caught. It’s why fundamentalist Christians ask what prevents an atheist from doing bad things. If an atheist doesn’t have a god watching, ready to punish them for eternity, what stops an atheist from doing whatever they want? Their own thoughts stop them. They don’t want to live in a society where people mistreat each other so they treat people the way they want to be treated. They thoughtfully consider how their actions affect others. People whose decisions are based on avoiding punishment have a harder time grasping that. Additionally, what adults don’t see are the spanked children who learn to hide their behavior. Being spanked lets the child know the spanker didn’t like their choice. But it doesn’t help the child make a better choice actually work. The “bad” ways work for what they want. So they learn to be sneaky. They may know not to hit their annoying little brother but they don’t know what to do instead. They can learn to pinch surreptitiously, bump them “accidentally”, whisper threats. As long as their parents can’t see it, they’ll get away with it. If they get caught and punished more severely it just increases their determination to be sneakier. The better they are at hiding their activities, the more oblivious adults are to the fact that spanking is not only not working, it’s making the situation worse. Some kids see spanking as part of the deal. They’ll weigh their actions against the expected punishment and likelihood of getting caught. If it seems worth it, they’ll go through with it and accept the later punishment. Anyone who believes spanking works isn’t seeing beyond the surface. They may believe kids who aren’t spanked will push boundaries as far as they can. They may be certain they would have done all sorts of bad things if they didn’t fear their parents’ punishment. They’re right. Once parents depend on punishment to correct behavior, their children think differently about right and wrong. Wrong is getting caught and punished. Right is whatever they can get away with. If a parent stops spanking, children will push to determine how far the new boundary that triggers spanking is. That’s because their morality isn’t based on how their actions affect others. It’s based on how it affects them.
